data.title: Where all the Indian truck drivers go.
data.text: All of the other Indian restaurants in this area are "northern" in style, meaning that they are ok, but watered down and overpriced. This one is completely vegetarian and has the truest flavors around. It's only a little deli in the back of the store, and the selections aren't plentiful, but they serve things you get no where else, and their samosas are by far the tastiest around. A great cheap place to eat. I go here at least once a week.

data.title: Good options but food preparation needs more finesse
data.text:
If you are looking for cheap food take away, then good option. However the food preparation needs more finesse as it looks more towards American taste rather Indian. The Pav Bhaji n Vada Pav are on the higher side of cost. Lassi is a good option. 

On top of that it has Indian groceries and a very wide variety of Sweets too. If you are looking for something in particular ask at the counter, they will be happy to guide you.

data.title: Good inexpensive fast Indian food
data.text: This restaurant has recently changed hands.  They serve good vegetarian Indian food but the place is short on chairs and tables.  Food is inexpensive but good.  You should not expect much in terms of service.  They have excellent samosas.

data.title: Indian grocery store and curry counter
data.text: Sort of fast food Indian style.  First time eating here.  I had the vegetarian curry, which was around $6.  A vegetable curry, a chickpea curry, and rice, with a spoon of chutney.  It also comes with a chapati bread, like tortilla.  Mine was not buttered which is how I like it, but i bet they can serve it with ghee if you wanted.  Served in a styrofoam to go container, even though I asked for it for here.  The store has some tables (hot) and there are a couple of more outside overlooking the parking lot of the mini-mall this place resides in.  The place is kind of dingy, not a place to take a date or business meeting.  But if you are in the area and want to quick curry, it does the job.  They also have fritters (samosas or pakoras), which I did not try, but will give a taste next time.
